large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: The One Day House

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to introduce the big book and identify it as a narrative about Wilson and Gigi.
Use Circle Time to introduce the vocabulary word (snug).
Use Circle Time to review the letters Ee, Kk, and Ll.
Begin Story Time by introducing the big book and asking the guiding question: What are some things Wilson plans on doing one day?
Read for enjoyment and understanding.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize at least 20 letter sounds; Identify at least 20 uppercase and 20 lowercase letters in isolation.
Participate in prereading and reading-related activities.
Show self-awareness in different/multiple ways.
Show understanding of text read aloud.
Understand a large number of words and begin to use more and more of those words.
Understand that people who speak the same language sometimes use different dialects or expressions.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Review the letters Ee, Kk, and Ll, and the sounds they make.
Allow children to uncover clues using paint, and find a partner with a matching letter.
Explore children’s vocabulary by finding words that contain these sounds and trying to define them.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What can we do better together?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What character is in your book? What’s special about that character?
Can you pretend you’re going to help fix Gigi’s house?
Can you draw a house with five windows?
Can you write what you like about your neighborhood?
Can you use these materials to make Gigi’s house?
Can you find things in your station that start with the letter e?
Build a fence using materials from the construction center.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: The One Day House

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to practice identifying and solving problems, and introduce related vocabulary words (solve problems, together).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to The One Day House.
Read closely to notice and talk about the Mind Builder.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Make inferences; Make predictions; Relate own experiences to those in books; Ask and answer questions about story elements.
Take initiative.
Show self-awareness in different/multiple ways.
Demonstrate empathy for others.
Identify and solve problems.
Show understanding of text read aloud.
Understand a large number of words and begin to use more and more of those words; Make connections between words and real life.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Connect to the Big Book by encouraging children to identify problems and find solutions like Wilson does.
Extend learning by comparing solutions and discussing consequences.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What can we do better together?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you identify the problem in the story?
Can you pretend to solve the problem of a broken chair?
Can you draw Gigi’s flower garden? How many flowers did you draw?
Write a story about a time you asked for help.
Can you use these materials to create Gigi’s flower garden?
Can you find things in your station that start with the letter k?
Can you build a house like Gigi’s?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. The One Day House by Julio Durango, illustrated by Bianca Diaz. Text copyright © 2011 by Julio Durango. Illustrations copyright © 2011 by Bianca Diaz. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Charlesbridge Publishing, Inc. large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: The One Day House

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background and teach vocabulary (cozy).
Start Story Time by revisiting The One Day House and asking the guiding question: Why does Wilson want to help Gigi?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize at least 20 letter sounds; Identify at least 20 uppercase and lowercase letters in text.
Make inferences; Make predictions; Ask and answer questions about story elements; Identify the role of author and illustrator.
Compose a narrative; Contribute ideas and participate in group writing.
Take initiative.
Identify connections and differences between feelings and behavior.
Identify emotions in others.
Show understanding of text read aloud.
Understand a large number of words and begin to use more and more of those words.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Literacy: Read-Aloud Comprehension; Alphabet Knowledge; Writing

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children create stories involving the letters Ee, Kk, and Ll.
Encourage children to speak using complete sentences.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What do we do better together?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How do the characters in your book work together?
Can you pretend to be someone that helps Gigi? What will you fix?
What is one tool you can use to measure something?
Write a story about how Wilson asked his neighbors to help Gigi.
Can you use these materials to make a dog for Gigi?
Can you find things in your station that start with the letter l?
Can you build a fence, like Gigi has in her yard?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. The One Day House by Julio Durango, illustrated by Bianca Diaz. Text copyright © 2011 by Julio Durango. Illustrations copyright © 2011 by Bianca Diaz. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Charlesbridge Publishing, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

tg_materials-caption.tg_materials-caption_book-title-Ital: Big Chart of Big Ideas: We Have Soup

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about teamwork, and introduce vocabulary (soup, peas).
Start Story Time by connecting the texts We Have Soup and The One Day House.
Read closely to make a connection with the weekly concept question, What do we do better together?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Select books and other texts for prereading.
Make inferences; Compare and contrast two stories relating to the same topic.
Take initiative.
Show understanding of text read aloud.
Understand a large number of words and begin to use more and more of those words.
Talk about roles and jobs of the people in their community.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Review the Big Chart of Big Ideas.
Encourage children to work as a team.
Ask them to complete an art project together.
Challenge them to discuss why we do some things better together than alone.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What do we do better together?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Did you find a book? Why did you pick this book?
Can you pretend to make soup for everyone?
Can you draw a bowl of vegetable soup? Count how many vegetables you used.
Can you write a story about making soup? Who will help you make the soup?
Can you fill this bowl with things to make soup?
Now let’s make Alphabet Soup using the tiles. See if you can spoon out a word!
Can you build the town of Rabbitville?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. The One Day House by Julio Durango, illustrated by Bianca Diaz. Text copyright © 2011 by Julio Durango. Illustrations copyright © 2011 by Bianca Diaz. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Charlesbridge Publishing, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Photos © Shutterstock: markers (nikkytok), paper (jannoon028).

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: The One Day House

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to actively engage children and teach vocabulary (keep you company).
Start Story Time by revisiting the book and asking the guiding question: How are you like Wilson?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Select books and other texts for prereading.
Write for different purposes.
Make inferences.
Show self-awareness in different/multiple ways.
Express pride in age-appropriate ways.
Take initiative.
Show understanding of text read aloud.
Understand a large number of words and begin to use more and more of those words.
Talk about roles and jobs of the people in their community.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: Tell about a time you worked together with many other people.
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s work to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What do we do better together?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you find a book you want to read? What do the pictures tell you about the book?
Can you pretend to be Wilson? Can you ask different people to help you fix Gigi’s house?
Can you draw the neighbors helping Wilson and Gigi? How many people did you draw?
Can you write about how you would help Gigi?
Can you use these materials to make the group of people helping Gigi?
Can you read an Alphabet Book to a friend?
Can you build a house that looks like Gigi’s house? Ask for help and work as a team!

Illustrations copyright © 2011 by Bianca Diaz. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Charlesbridge Publishing, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize at least 20 distinct letter sounds in the language of instruction.
Engage in pre-reading and reading-related activities.
Show self-awareness and can express pride in age appropriate abilities and skills.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Demonstrate understanding of terms used in the language of the classroom.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Demonstrate understanding in a variety of ways or knowing the meaning of 3,000 to 4,000 words, many more than he or she uses.
Will make inferences and predictions about text.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Demonstrate understanding of terms used in the instructional language of the classroom.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Show initiative in independent situations and persist in attempting to solve problems.
Initiate problem-solving strategies and seek adult help when necessary.
Demonstrate empathy and caring for others.
Show self-awareness and express pride in age appropriate abilities and skills.
Recognize at least 20 distinct letter sounds in the language of instruction.
Will make inferences and predictions about text.
Ask and respond to questions relevant to the text read aloud.
Show initiative in independent situations and persist in attempting to solve problems.
Initiate problem-solving strategies and seek adult help when necessary.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Demonstrate understanding of terms used in the instructional language of the classroom.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Demonstrate understanding in a variety of ways or knowing the meaning of 3,000 to 4,000 words, many more than he or she uses.
Self-select books and other written materials to engage in pre-reading behaviors.
Will make inferences and predictions about text.
Show initiative in independent situations and persist in attempting to solve problems.
Initiate problem-solving strategies and seek adult help when necessary.
Demonstrate understanding in terms used in the instructional language of the classroom.
Demonstrate understanding in a variety of ways or knowing the meaning of 3,000 to 4,000 words, many more than he or she uses.
Discuss the roles and responsibilities of family, school, and community helpers.
Self-select books and other written materials to engage in pre-reading behaviors.
Independently write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
Will make inferences and predictions about text.
Show self-awareness and can express pride in age-appropriate abilities and skills.
Show initiative in independent situations and persist in attempting to solve problems.
Initiate problem-solving strategies and seek adult help when necessary.
Discuss the roles and responsibilities of family, school, and community helpers.
